page.title: 06JEDBURGH KILTMAKERS
page.content: JEDBURGH. The building, which is of good appearance, is owned by Moffat Weavers. Kilts are made at the rear of the premises. The tartan material starts off in big bales, then it goes to the cutting tables where a man snips the cloth, and a lady puts hems on. The cloth goes through a pleating machine then into a boiler to keep the pleat. In another room, forty people turn them into kilts by putting on buckles etc. then they are checked. About 300 are produced each day. In the shop, there are six permanent workers, but in the Summer there are nearly thirty. There is a licensed cafe for snacks or hot meals. Besides kilts the shop sells jumpers, skirts and blouses, also perfume. Kilts are exported all over the world. Often up to six buses can be seen disgorging tourists into the premises
